page_content='Archaeological Monitoring 

The areas identified in Figure 17 within the red line boundary, were be plotted on construction plans and 
marked out on the ground prior to the investigation. 

The supervising archaeologist position himself in a safe location where the working area was visible and 
instructions could be conveyed to the demolition contractors. The ground surface in areas subject to 
works was then scraped off in 20cm to expose any features. The excavator scraped the tops of the 
buried concrete and brick footings for the full length of their exposure and this area was mapped and 
photographed. Measurements were taken of sections of the footings and individual bricks. 

The mechanical excavator removed segments of the footings, exposing the base material and fill on 
either side. A section was cut through the footing trench to determine how deep and wide the 
foundation trench was originally cut.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5190_Consent to Damage (C1746) report, Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641).pdf'}

page_content='© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

III 

 
\x0c1  Introduction 

This report presents the results of archaeological investigations under a Consent to Damage (C1746) for 
Former Raywood Railway Station (H7724-0641), issued by Heritage Victoria on 21 October 2021. 

It has been developed in accordance with the consent conditions and information provided by V/Line. 

1.1  Location of study areas 

The study area for Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641) is located between the Midland 
Highway and Reilly Street. 

The location of the study areas are shown in Figure 1. 

Figure 1 

Location and extent of Bagshot Station 

© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

4 

 
 
 
\x0c2  Background

3.paragraph: The excavation site is located in the township of Bairnsdale, approximately 15 km east of the city of Traralgon in the Gippsland region of Victoria.
source:
page_content='© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

III 

 
\x0c1  Introduction 

This report presents the results of archaeological investigations under a Consent to Damage (C1746) for 
Former Raywood Railway Station (H7724-0641), issued by Heritage Victoria on 21 October 2021. 

It has been developed in accordance with the consent conditions and information provided by V/Line. 

1.1  Location of study areas 

The study area for Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641) is located between the Midland 
Highway and Reilly Street. 

The location of the study areas are shown in Figure 1. 

Figure 1 

Location and extent of Bagshot Station 

© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

4 

 
 
 
\x0c2  Background 

2.1  Site history' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5190_Consent to Damage (C1746) report, Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641).pdf'}

page_content='It is maintained by Victorian Rail amateur historians that railway platforms were built up by any 
soils/gravels quarried nearby and any other sort of fill available. This being the case it is most likely that 
the contents of the platform (falling within the brick foundations) were mechanically pushed back to 
form the mound that now stand behind (to the west) of the platform. It is possible that any railway 
station building foundations/remains – including possible telegraph office, (most likely one and the same 
building - and most likely of timber construction) associated with the platform may lie under this mound. 

© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

10 

 
 
 
 
\x0cAerial images indicate a rectangular enclosure measuring about 25 by 30 metres to the west of the 
platform on adjoining land, with other features suggesting a structure present within it. This is likely 
where the departmental residence (stationmaster’s house) was located (see Figure 9).' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5190_Consent to Damage (C1746) report, Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641).pdf'}

page_content='The footings were excavated into natural clay by about 400mm, and as there was no evidence of buried 
topsoil, it can be assumed that the ground level had been cut down prior to construction of the 
permanent way and ballasting, so that all of the structure visible parallel to the tracks at the time of the 
investigation, would have been buried and out of sight when the station was operating. 

No Aboriginal artefacts or other cultural heritage was identified during the investigation. 

Figure 18  Exposed brick and concrete platform edge footing prior to removal 

© Biosis 2022 – Leaders in Ecology and Heritage Consulting  

18 

 
 
\x0cFigure 19  Extent of platform edge exposed during site investigaitons' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5190_Consent to Damage (C1746) report, Former Bagshot Railway Station (H7724-0641).pdf'}
